Dave,

An example showing the large discrepancy between equilibrium and
equ=
ilibrium obtained with a 1D flame calculation can be observed by
running th=
e default script *adiabatic_flame.py* and an equilibrium
calculation using =
the same initial mixture with the default GRI3.0
mechanism.

Equilibrium te=
mp: 2134K

Equil. Temp obtained with flame calculation: 2138K

I had assign=
ed this problem to my students in a combust. class, and to
my disbelief, th=
e temperatures and composition differed substantially
between equilibrium a=
nd flame calculations.

best,

matei



--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Da=
ve Goodwin" <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
>
> Could you send me an example flame sc=
ript or program that shows the
problem? Thanks.
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogr=
oups.com, "Matei I. Radulescu" <matei@> wrote:
> >
> > When one computes th=
e the free-flame structure (say H2+air at PTN),
> > the equilibrium tempera=
ture obtained is different from the true
> > adiabatic flame temperature ob=
tained via a direct equilibrium
> > calculation, using the same thermo data=
.  The differences are on the
> > order of 10K for the example given.  Like=
wise, the enthalpy in the
> > flame of the equilibrium products is NOT foun=
d equal to reactants
> > enthalpy, although theoretically, they should be e=
qual.  This leads me
> > to suspect that the non-conservative flame calcula=
tions introduces
> > order 1 errors in the species concentrations of the pr=
oducts,
> > consistent with the results of the simulations!  Are these
> > =
*acceptable* errors???
> >
>
